column4: I just upadated my system from Dapper to Edgy. I see now that Edgy is using UUID to designate harddrives. I keep a cloned backup of my hd on another hd. Will I have problem booting if the UUID doesn't work on the different hd?
I can see maybe using UUIDs for removable drives, but this is a real step backwards to force it into Grub
anyone know if I'd break things using /dev/ instead of UUID in Grub?
UUID's shouldn't be used in Grub for the very reason I've cited. This completely screws up disk cloning.
it's worse than DRM as far as i'm concerned!
what developer with Ubuntu is responsible to for this change to UUID in Grub and how to I reach him?
The one with the evil eyes. If you find a way to reach him through the screen, tell me too. :)
make fun if you want. but this is really serious and crippling
You can use the old format if you want. Just change it manually.
after making changes to menu.lst do I just reboot or is something else required?
Nope, just reboot. Grub reads that file every time.
of course! only when adding a new line to fstab will mount -a by itself work
Any way that works by default?
Something that works with a default nautilus. Something that doesn't have to be configured.
there wouldn't be an addon script if it already existed, would there?
Well that's what I was asking.
